home.title: R Tutorial
paragraphs: Learn R
R is a programming language.
R is often used for statistical computing and graphical presentation to analyze and visualize data.
We recommend reading this tutorial, in the sequence listed in the left menu.

sections.heading: Start Learning R
paragraphs: Start learning R now »

sections.heading: Tip
paragraphs: Tip: Sign in to track your progress.

sections.heading: Examples in Each Chapter
paragraphs: With our "Try it Yourself" editor, you can edit R code and view the result.

examples.heading: Example
examples.description: How to output some text, and how to do a simple calculation in R:

examples.heading: Example
examples.description: How you can use R to easily create a graph with numbers from 1 to 10 on both the x and y axis:

paragraphs: Test Yourself With Exercises

exercise.question: Insert the missing part of the code below to output "Hello World".

sections.heading: R Quiz
paragraphs: Learn by taking a quiz! This quiz will give you a signal of how much you know about R.
Take the R Quiz

sections.heading: R Examples
paragraphs: Learn by examples! This tutorial supplements all explanations with clarifying examples.
See All R Examples

sections.heading: Track Your Progress
paragraphs: Create a W3Schools account and get access to more features and learning materials:
list: View your completed tutorials, exercises, and quizzes
Keep an eye on your progress and daily streaks
Join the leaderboard and compete with others
Get your own avatar and unlock new skins
sections.note: Note: This is an optional feature. You can study at W3Schools without creating an account.

intro.title: R Introduction
paragraphs: What is R
R is a popular programming language used for statistical computing and graphical presentation.
Its most common use is to analyze and visualize data.

sections.heading: Why Use R?
list: It is a great resource for data analysis, data visualization, data science and machine learning
It provides many statistical techniques (such as statistical tests, classification, clustering and data reduction)
It is easy to draw graphs in R, like pie charts, histograms, box plot, scatter plot, etc++
It works on different platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux)
It has a large community support
It has many packages (libraries of functions) that can be used to solve different problems

sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: This tutorial will teach you the basics of R.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.
Get Started Now »

get-started.title: R Get Started
paragraphs: How to Install R
To install R, go to https://cloud.r-project.org/ and download the latest version of R for Windows, Mac or Linux.
When you have downloaded and installed R, you can run R on your computer.
The screenshot below shows how it may look like when you run R on a Windows PC:
If you type 5 + 5, and press enter, you will see that R outputs 10.

sections.heading: Learning R at W3Schools
paragraphs: When learning R at W3Schools.com, you can use our "Try it Yourself" tool, which shows both the code and the result in your browser.
This will make it easier for you to test and understand every part as we move forward:

sections.heading: R Syntax
content: R syntax is used to write instructions that R can understand and execute.
R allows output of text, numbers, and calculations using simple and readable commands.

sections.heading: Output Text
content: To output text in R, you can use either single quotes or double quotes.

sections.heading: Output Numbers
content: To output numbers in R, simply type the number without using quotes.

sections.heading: Simple Calculations
content: R can perform basic arithmetic operations such as addition.

sections.heading: Note
content: You have now written your first R code using basic R syntax.

sections.heading: R Comments
content: Comments are used to explain R code and make it more readable.
They can also be used to prevent code from being executed while testing.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
content: In R, comments start with the # character.
Anything that comes after # on a line is ignored by R.

sections.heading: End-of-line Comments
content: Comments can also be written at the end of a line of code.

sections.heading: Using Comments to Disable Code
content: Comments can be used to prevent R from executing specific lines of code.

sections.heading: Multiline Comments
content: R does not support multiline comment syntax like some other programming languages.
To create multiline comments, add # at the beginning of each line.
sections.example:
# This is a comment
# written in
# more than just one line
"Hello World!"

sections.heading: Creating Variables in R
content: Variables are containers for storing data values.
In R, a variable is created the moment a value is assigned to it.
To assign a value to a variable, use the <- operator.
To output the value of a variable, simply type the variable name.

sections.heading: Assignment Operators
content: In R, both <- and = can be used as assignment operators.
The <- operator is preferred because = can be restricted in some contexts.

sections.heading: Print / Output Variables
content: Unlike many other programming languages, R automatically prints the value of a variable when you type its name.

sections.heading: Using the print() Function
content: R also provides a print() function to output variable values.
This can be useful for users familiar with other languages like Python.

sections.heading: Printing Inside Code Blocks
content: When working inside expressions such as loops or code blocks, the print() function is required to display output.

sections.heading: Conclusion
content: You can choose whether to use print() or not for output.
However, inside curly braces {} or expressions, print() must be used to display results.

sections.heading: Data Types
content: In programming, data types define what kind of data a variable can store.
Variables can store different types of data, and different data types can perform different operations.

sections.heading: Dynamic Typing in R
content: In R, variables do not need to be declared with a specific data type.
A variable can change its data type after it has been assigned.

sections.heading: Basic Data Types in R
content: R provides several basic data types.

sections.heading: Checking Data Types
content: The class() function is used to check the data type of a variable.

sections.heading: Note
content: You will learn more about each data type in the upcoming chapters.

sections.heading: Numbers
content: R supports different types of numbers for mathematical operations.
There are three main number types in R: numeric, integer, and complex.

sections.heading: Number Types in R
content: numeric
integer
complex
sections.example:
x <- 10.5   # numeric
y <- 10L    # integer
z <- 1i     # complex

sections.heading: Numeric
content: Numeric is the most common number type in R.
It includes numbers with or without decimal points.

sections.heading: Integer
content: Integers are whole numbers without decimals.
To create an integer in R, append the letter L to the value.

sections.heading: Complex
content: Complex numbers contain an imaginary part represented by i.

sections.heading: Type Conversion
content: R provides functions to convert numbers between different types.
Common conversion functions include as.numeric(), as.integer(), and as.complex().
sections.example:
x <- 1L
y <- 2

# convert from integer to numeric
a <- as.numeric(x)

# convert from numeric to integer
b <- as.integer(y)

x
y

class(a)
class(b)

sections.heading: Simple Math
content: In R, operators are used to perform common mathematical operations on numbers.

sections.heading: Addition
content: The + operator is used to add two values.

sections.heading: Subtraction
content: The - operator is used to subtract one value from another.

sections.heading: Note
content: R provides many more operators for mathematical operations, which are covered in the R Operators tutorial.

sections.heading: Built-in Math Functions
content: R includes built-in functions to perform common mathematical calculations.

sections.heading: Minimum and Maximum
content: The min() and max() functions return the smallest and largest values in a set.

sections.heading: Square Root
content: The sqrt() function returns the square root of a number.

sections.heading: Absolute Value
content: The abs() function returns the absolute (positive) value of a number.

sections.heading: Rounding Numbers
content: The ceiling() function rounds a number up to the nearest integer.
The floor() function rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

sections.heading: String Literals
content: Strings are used for storing text.
In R, strings can be enclosed in either single quotes or double quotes.
Single-quoted and double-quoted strings behave the same way.

sections.heading: Assign a String to a Variable
content: Strings can be assigned to variables using the <- operator.
Typing the variable name will output the string value.

sections.heading: Multiline Strings
content: R allows multiline strings by including line breaks inside quotes.
R automatically inserts the \n escape character at each line break.
sections.example:
str <- "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit,
sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt
ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."

str

sections.heading: Printing Multiline Strings
content: To preserve line breaks exactly as written in the code, use the cat() function.

sections.heading: String Length
content: The nchar() function returns the number of characters in a string.

sections.heading: Check a String
content: The grepl() function checks whether a pattern exists in a string.
It returns TRUE if the pattern is found, otherwise FALSE.
sections.example:
str <- "Hello World!"

grepl("H", str)
grepl("Hello", str)
grepl("X", str)

sections.heading: Combine Two Strings
content: The paste() function is used to concatenate two or more strings.

sections.heading: Booleans (Logical Values)
content: In programming, boolean values are used to determine whether an expression is true or false.
R evaluates expressions and returns one of two logical values: TRUE or FALSE.

sections.heading: Comparing Values
content: When comparing two values, R evaluates the expression and returns a logical result.

sections.heading: Comparing Variables
content: Logical comparisons can also be made between variables.

sections.heading: Booleans in if Statements
content: Logical values are commonly used in if...else statements to control program flow.

sections.heading: Operators
content: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.
For example, the + operator adds two values together.

sections.heading: Operator Categories
content: R divides operators into the following groups:
Arithmetic operators
Assignment operators
Comparison operators
Logical operators
Miscellaneous operators

sections.heading: R Assignment Operators
content: Assignment operators are used to assign values to variables.
The direction of assignment can be reversed.

sections.heading: Note
content: <<- is a global assignment operator.
x <- 3 is equivalent to 3 -> x.

rows: Checks if element exists in vector

sections.heading: Conditions and If Statements
content: R supports common comparison operators used in mathematics.
These conditions are mostly used in if statements and loops.

sections.heading: The if Statement
content: The if statement executes a block of code if a condition is TRUE.
Curly braces { } define the scope of the code block.

sections.heading: Else If
content: The else if keyword checks a new condition if the previous condition was FALSE.
You can use multiple else if statements.

sections.heading: If Else
content: The else keyword runs when none of the previous conditions are TRUE.
Else can also be used without else if.

sections.heading: Loops
content: Loops execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is TRUE.
They help save time, reduce errors, and make code more readable.
R supports two types of loops: while loops and for loops.

sections.heading: R While Loops
content: A while loop executes a set of statements as long as its condition remains TRUE.
An indexing variable must be defined before the loop starts.
Always remember to update the variable to avoid infinite loops.

sections.heading: Break
content: The break statement stops the loop even if the condition is still TRUE.
It is useful when a specific condition is met and the loop should terminate early.

sections.heading: Next
content: The next statement skips the current iteration without stopping the loop.
Execution continues with the next iteration.

sections.heading: If Else Combined with a While Loop
content: Conditional statements can be used inside while loops.
This allows different actions depending on the loop value.

sections.heading: For Loops
content: A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence.
It executes a block of code once for each item in a sequence such as a vector, list, or array.
Unlike while loops, a for loop does not require an indexing variable to be set beforehand.

sections.heading: Looping Through Collections
content: A for loop can iterate through lists, vectors, and other collections.
Each element in the collection is assigned to the loop variable one by one.

sections.heading: Break
content: The break statement stops the loop before it finishes iterating through all items.
It is useful when a specific condition is met and the loop should terminate early.

sections.heading: Next
content: The next statement skips the current iteration without stopping the loop.
Execution continues with the next item in the sequence.

sections.heading: If Else Combined with a For Loop
content: Conditional statements can be combined with for loops to perform different actions based on values.
This allows more flexible and practical looping logic.

functions.title: R Functions
overview: A function is a block of code that runs only when it is called.
Functions can take inputs (arguments/parameters) and return outputs.
They help organize code, reduce repetition, and improve readability.

sections.heading: Creating a Function
content: Functions are created using the function() keyword.
The function body is written inside curly braces {}.

sections.heading: Calling a Function
content: To execute a function, use its name followed by parentheses ().

sections.heading: Arguments (Parameters)
content: Arguments allow you to pass values into a function.
You can define one or more arguments, separated by commas.

sections.heading: Parameters vs Arguments
content: A parameter is the variable listed in the function definition.
An argument is the actual value passed to the function when it is called.

sections.heading: Number of Arguments
content: By default, a function must be called with the exact number of arguments it defines.
Calling with too few or too many arguments results in an error.

sections.heading: Default Parameter Values
content: You can assign default values to parameters.
If no argument is provided, the default value is used.

sections.heading: Return Values
content: Functions can return values using the return() statement.
The returned value can be stored or printed.

data-structures.title: R Data Structures
overview: Data structures are used to store and organize values.
R provides several built-in data structures, each suited for different use cases.

sections.heading: Vectors
content: Vectors are the most basic data structure in R.
They store elements of the same data type.

sections.heading: Lists
content: Lists can store elements of different data types.
They can contain numbers, strings, vectors, and even other lists.

sections.heading: Matrices
content: Matrices are two-dimensional data structures.
All elements in a matrix must be of the same type.

sections.heading: Arrays
content: Arrays are similar to matrices but can have more than two dimensions.
They store elements of the same type.
sections.example:
thisarray <- c(1:24)
multiarray <- array(thisarray, dim = c(4, 3, 2))
multiarray

sections.heading: Data Frames
content: Data frames are similar to tables or spreadsheets.
Each column can contain different data types.
sections.example:
Data_Frame <- data.frame(
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)
Data_Frame

summary: Data Frame → tabular data with mixed types

sections.heading: Vectors
content: A vector is a list of items that are all of the same type.
Vectors are created using the c() function.

sections.heading: Create Vectors
content: Use the c() function to combine values into a vector.
sections.example:
# Vector of strings
fruits <- c("banana", "apple", "orange")
fruits

sections.heading: Numeric Vectors
content: Vectors can also store numeric values.
sections.example:
# Vector of numbers
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3)
numbers

sections.heading: Sequence Vectors
content: Use the : operator to create a sequence of numbers.

sections.heading: Decimal Sequences
content: Decimal sequences increase by 1 unless specified otherwise.
If the last value does not fit the sequence, it is ignored.

sections.heading: Logical Vectors
content: Vectors can also contain logical (TRUE/FALSE) values.
sections.example:
log_values <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE)
log_values

sections.heading: Vector Length
content: Use the length() function to find the number of elements in a vector.

sections.heading: Sort Vectors
content: Use the sort() function to sort vectors alphabetically or numerically.

sections.heading: Access Vector Elements
content: Access elements using index positions.
Indexing in R starts at 1.

sections.heading: Modify Vector Elements
content: You can change elements by assigning a new value to an index.

sections.heading: Repeat Vectors
content: Use the rep() function to repeat vector values.

sections.heading: Generate Sequences with seq()
content: Use seq() to create sequences with custom steps.

sections.heading: Lists
content: A list in R can contain many different data types.
Lists are ordered and changeable collections.

sections.heading: Create a List
content: Use the list() function to create a list.
sections.example:
# List of strings
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
thislist

sections.heading: Access List Items
content: Access list items using index numbers.
Indexing in R starts at 1.

sections.heading: Change Item Value
content: Modify a list item by assigning a new value to its index.

sections.heading: List Length
content: Use the length() function to find the number of items in a list.

sections.heading: Check if Item Exists
content: Use the %in% operator to check if an item exists in a list.

sections.heading: Add List Items
content: Use the append() function to add items to a list.
You can specify the position using the after parameter.

sections.heading: Remove List Items
content: Remove items by excluding their index using negative indexing.

sections.heading: Range of Indexes
content: Use the : operator to access a range of list items.

sections.heading: Loop Through a List
content: Use a for loop to iterate through list items.

sections.heading: Join Two Lists
content: Use the c() function to combine multiple lists.
sections.example:
list1 <- list("a", "b", "c")
list2 <- list(1, 2, 3)
list3 <- c(list1, list2)
list3

sections.heading: Matrices
content: A matrix is a two dimensional data set with columns and rows.
Matrices can store data in a tabular format.

sections.heading: Create a Matrix
content: Use the matrix() function to create a matrix.
Specify the number of rows and columns using nrow and ncol.
sections.example:
# Create a matrix
thismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)
thismatrix

sections.heading: Matrix with Strings
content: Matrices can also contain character values.

sections.heading: Access Matrix Items
content: Access items using row and column indexes.
Indexing in R starts at 1.

sections.heading: Access Entire Row
content: Specify a row number followed by a comma to access an entire row.

sections.heading: Access Entire Column
content: Specify a column number before the comma to access an entire column.

sections.heading: Access Multiple Rows
content: Use the c() function to access more than one row.

sections.heading: Access Multiple Columns
content: Use the c() function to access more than one column.

sections.heading: Add Columns
content: Use the cbind() function to add columns to a matrix.

sections.heading: Add Rows
content: Use the rbind() function to add rows to a matrix.

sections.heading: Remove Rows and Columns
content: Remove rows or columns using negative indexing.

sections.heading: Check if Item Exists
content: Use the %in% operator to check if an item exists in a matrix.

sections.heading: Matrix Dimensions
content: Use the dim() function to get the number of rows and columns.

sections.heading: Matrix Length
content: Use the length() function to get the total number of elements.

sections.heading: Loop Through a Matrix
content: Use nested for loops to iterate through matrix rows and columns.

sections.heading: Combine Matrices
content: Use rbind() to combine matrices by rows.
Use cbind() to combine matrices by columns.
sections.example:
Matrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "grape"), nrow = 2)
Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango", "pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2)
rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)

sections.heading: Arrays
content: Compared to matrices, arrays can have more than two dimensions.
Arrays can only contain one data type.

sections.heading: Create an Array
content: Use the array() function to create an array.
Use the dim parameter to specify the dimensions.
sections.example:
# An array with one dimension
thisarray <- c(1:24)
thisarray

# An array with more than one dimension
multiarray <- array(thisarray, dim = c(4, 3, 2))
multiarray

sections.heading: Example Explained
content: The values 1 to 24 are stored in an array.
The first two numbers in dim specify rows and columns.
The last number specifies the number of dimensions.

sections.heading: Access Array Items
content: Access elements by specifying their index positions.
Indexing in R starts at 1.

sections.heading: Access Rows in an Array
content: Use c() after the comma to access a row from a matrix level.

sections.heading: Access Columns in an Array
content: Use c() before the comma to access a column from a matrix level.

sections.heading: Check if Item Exists
content: Use the %in% operator to check if a value exists in an array.

sections.heading: Array Dimensions
content: Use the dim() function to get the number of rows, columns, and dimensions.

sections.heading: Array Length
content: Use the length() function to get the total number of elements.

sections.heading: Loop Through an Array
content: Use a for loop to iterate through array elements.

sections.heading: Data Frames
content: Data Frames are data displayed in a format as a table.
Each column can contain different data types, but each column must contain the same type of data.

sections.heading: Create a Data Frame
content: Use the data.frame() function to create a data frame.
sections.example:
# Create a data frame
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

Data_Frame

sections.heading: Summarize the Data
content: Use the summary() function to summarize the data in a data frame.

sections.heading: Access Items
content: Use single brackets, double brackets, or the $ operator to access columns.

sections.heading: Add Rows
content: Use the rbind() function to add new rows to a data frame.

sections.heading: Add Columns
content: Use the cbind() function to add new columns to a data frame.

sections.heading: Remove Rows and Columns
content: Use negative indexing with the c() function to remove rows or columns.

sections.heading: Amount of Rows and Columns
content: Use the dim() function to get the number of rows and columns.
You can also use nrow() and ncol().

sections.heading: Data Frame Length
content: Use the length() function to get the number of columns in a data frame.

sections.heading: Combine Data Frames (Rows)
content: Use the rbind() function to combine data frames vertically.

sections.heading: Combine Data Frames (Columns)
content: Use the cbind() function to combine data frames horizontally.

sections.heading: Factors
content: Factors are used to categorize data.
Common examples include demographic data, music genres, and training types.

sections.heading: Create a Factor
content: Use the factor() function to create a factor from a vector.
sections.example:
# Create a factor
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

music_genre

sections.heading: Factor Levels
content: A factor contains unique categories called levels.
Levels are determined automatically from the data.

sections.heading: Set Factor Levels
content: You can manually define factor levels using the levels argument.
sections.example:
music_genre <- factor(
  c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"),
  levels = c("Classic", "Jazz", "Pop", "Rock", "Other")
)

levels(music_genre)

sections.heading: Factor Length
content: Use the length() function to find the number of items in a factor.

sections.heading: Access Factor Items
content: Access factor values using index numbers.

sections.heading: Change Item Value
content: You can change a factor value only if the new value already exists as a level.

sections.heading: Invalid Factor Level
content: Assigning a value that is not a predefined level will result in NA.

sections.heading: Add New Levels
content: To assign new values, include them when defining factor levels.
sections.example:
music_genre <- factor(
  c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"),
  levels = c("Classic", "Jazz", "Pop", "Rock", "Opera")
)

music_genre[3] <- "Opera"

music_genre[3]

sections.heading: Plot
content: The plot() function is used to draw points (markers) in a diagram.
It takes parameters for specifying points on the x-axis and y-axis.

sections.heading: Plot a Single Point
content: At its simplest, plot() can be used to draw one point.

sections.heading: Plot Multiple Points
content: Use vectors to draw more than one point.
Both axes must contain the same number of values.

sections.heading: Plot Many Points
content: You can plot as many points as you like as long as the x and y vectors have equal length.

sections.heading: Using Variables
content: Using variables makes plots easier to read and manage.

sections.heading: Sequences of Points
content: Use the : operator to create a sequence of points.

sections.heading: Draw a Line
content: Use the type parameter with value "l" to connect points with a line.

sections.heading: Plot Labels
content: Use main, xlab, and ylab to customize the plot title and axis labels.
sections.example: plot(1:10, main="My Graph", xlab="The x-axis", ylab="The y axis")

sections.heading: Plot Color
content: Use the col parameter to change the color of the points.

sections.heading: Point Size
content: Use the cex parameter to change the size of the points.

sections.heading: Point Shape
content: Use the pch parameter to change the shape of points.
Valid values range from 0 to 25.

sections.heading: Line Graphs
content: A line graph has a line that connects all the points in a diagram.

sections.heading: Create a Line Graph
content: Use the plot() function with the type parameter set to "l".

sections.heading: Line Color
content: The default line color is black.
Use the col parameter to change the color.

sections.heading: Line Width
content: Use the lwd parameter to control the width of the line.

sections.heading: Line Styles
content: Use the lty parameter to change the line style.
Valid values range from 0 to 6.

sections.heading: Line Style Values
content: 0 removes the line.
1 displays a solid line.
2 displays a dashed line.
3 displays a dotted line.
4 displays a dot-dashed line.
5 displays a long dashed line.
6 displays a two dashed line.

sections.heading: Multiple Lines
content: Use the lines() function to add additional lines to a graph.
sections.example:
line1 <- c(1,2,3,4,5,10)
line2 <- c(2,5,7,8,9,10)

plot(line1, type="l", col="blue")
lines(line2, type="l", col="red")

sections.heading: Scatter Plots
content: A scatter plot is used to display the relationship between two numerical variables.
Each observation is represented by one dot in the diagram.

sections.heading: Create a Scatter Plot
content: Use the plot() function with two vectors of equal length.
One vector represents the x-axis and the other represents the y-axis.

sections.heading: Add Plot Labels
content: Use main, xlab, and ylab to describe the scatter plot more clearly.
sections.example: plot(x, y, main="Observation of Cars", xlab="Car age", ylab="Car speed")

sections.heading: Understanding the Observation
content: The x-axis represents the age of the car.
The y-axis represents the speed of the car.
Scatter plots help identify possible relationships between variables.

sections.heading: Compare Scatter Plots
content: Use the points() function to add another data set to the same plot.
Assign different colors to distinguish between observations.

sections.heading: Scatter Plot Conclusion
content: Comparing multiple scatter plots can help confirm trends.
In this example, newer cars tend to have higher speeds.

sections.heading: Pie Charts
content: A pie chart is a circular graphical representation of data.
Each slice represents a proportion of the whole.

sections.heading: Create a Pie Chart
content: Use the pie() function to draw a pie chart.
sections.example:
# Create a vector of values
x <- c(10,20,30,40)

pie(x)

sections.heading: Example Explained
content: Each value in the vector represents one slice of the pie.
The size of each slice is calculated as value divided by the sum of all values.

sections.heading: Start Angle
content: Use the init.angle parameter to change the starting angle of the pie chart.
The default angle is 0 degrees.

sections.heading: Labels and Title
content: Use the label parameter to add labels to the pie chart.
Use the main parameter to add a title.
sections.example:
mylabel <- c("Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries", "Dates")

pie(x, label = mylabel, main = "Fruits")

sections.heading: Pie Chart Colors
content: Use the col parameter to assign colors to each slice.
sections.example:
colors <- c("blue", "yellow", "green", "black")

pie(x, label = mylabel, main = "Fruits", col = colors)

sections.heading: Add a Legend
content: Use the legend() function to explain the pie chart slices.
Legends can be positioned in various locations.
sections.example:
pie(x, label = mylabel, main = "Pie Chart", col = colors)

legend("bottomright", mylabel, fill = colors)

sections.heading: Legend Positions
content: Available positions include bottomright, bottom, bottomleft, left, topleft, top, topright, right, and center.

sections.heading: Bar Charts
content: A bar chart uses rectangular bars to visualize data.
Bars can be displayed vertically or horizontally, and their size represents values.

sections.heading: Create a Bar Chart
content: Use the barplot() function to draw a vertical bar chart.
sections.example:
# x-axis values
x <- c("A", "B", "C", "D")

# y-axis values
y <- c(2, 4, 6, 8)

barplot(y, names.arg = x)

sections.heading: Example Explained
content: The x variable represents labels on the x-axis.
The y variable represents the numeric values.
The names.arg parameter assigns labels to each bar.

sections.heading: Bar Color
content: Use the col parameter to change the color of the bars.

sections.heading: Bar Texture
content: Use the density parameter to change the texture of the bars.

sections.heading: Bar Width
content: Use the width parameter to control the width of each bar.

sections.heading: Horizontal Bars
content: Use the horiz parameter with TRUE to display bars horizontally.

sections.heading: Statistics Introduction
content: Statistics is the science of analyzing, reviewing, and drawing conclusions from data.
R was developed by statisticians and includes many built-in tools for statistical analysis.

sections.heading: Basic Statistical Concepts
content: Mean, median, and mode
Minimum and maximum values
Percentiles
Variance and standard deviation
Covariance and correlation
Probability distributions

sections.heading: Why Use R for Statistics
content: R provides built-in statistical functions.
R supports advanced statistical analysis through libraries.
R is widely used in data science, research, and analytics.

sections.heading: Next Steps
content: You will learn how to calculate and apply statistical measures in the following chapters.
If you are new to statistics, studying basic statistical theory will help you understand R statistics better.

sections.heading: Data Set
content: A data set is a collection of data, often presented in a table.
Data sets are commonly used for statistical analysis and visualization.

sections.heading: Built-in Data Set
content: R includes built-in data sets for learning and analysis.
One popular built-in data set is mtcars, taken from the 1974 Motor Trend US magazine.

sections.heading: View the Data Set
content: Use the dataset name to print its contents.
sections.example:
# Print the mtcars data set
mtcars

sections.heading: Using Data Sets for Statistics
content: The mtcars data set will be used in upcoming examples.
It contains information about fuel consumption and automobile performance.

sections.heading: Get Data Set Information
content: Use the question mark operator to view documentation about a data set.

sections.heading: Data Set Description
content: The mtcars data set contains 32 observations on 11 numeric variables.
Each row represents a car model and each column represents a specific measurement.

sections.heading: Data Set Variables
content: mpg: Miles per US gallon
cyl: Number of cylinders
disp: Displacement (cu.in.)
hp: Gross horsepower
drat: Rear axle ratio
wt: Weight (1000 lbs)
qsec: Quarter mile time
vs: Engine type (0 = V-shaped, 1 = straight)
am: Transmission (0 = automatic, 1 = manual)
gear: Number of forward gears
carb: Number of carburetors

sections.heading: Max and Min
content: The max() and min() functions are used to find the highest and lowest values in a data set.
They are commonly used in statistical analysis.

sections.heading: Find Maximum and Minimum Values
content: Use max() and min() to find the largest and smallest values in a variable.

sections.heading: Understanding the Result
content: The largest horsepower value in the data set is 335.
The smallest horsepower value in the data set is 52.

sections.heading: Find Index Positions
content: Use which.max() and which.min() to find the index of maximum and minimum values.

sections.heading: Find Row Names
content: Combine which.max() and which.min() with rownames() to identify the observation names.

sections.heading: Max and Min as Outliers
content: Maximum and minimum values can help detect outliers.
Outliers are data points that differ significantly from other observations.

sections.heading: Outlier Examples
content: An unusually high number of gears.
A horsepower value of zero.
An extremely high vehicle weight.

sections.heading: Mean
content: The mean is the average value of a set of numbers.
It is calculated by dividing the sum of all values by the number of values.

sections.heading: Mean in Statistics
content: Mean is one of the three most common measures of central tendency.
The other two are median and mode.

sections.heading: Calculate the Mean
content: Use the mean() function to calculate the average value of a variable.

sections.heading: Understanding the Result
content: The result represents the average weight of cars in the data set.
In this example, the mean weight is approximately 3.217.

sections.heading: Percentiles
content: Percentiles describe the value below which a given percentage of observations fall.
They are commonly used to understand the distribution of data.

sections.heading: Percentiles in Practice
content: Percentiles help determine how values are spread within a data set.
For example, the 75th percentile means 75% of the values are lower than or equal to that value.

sections.heading: Calculate a Specific Percentile
content: Use the quantile() function to calculate a specific percentile.
Specify the desired percentile using the c() function.

sections.heading: Multiple Percentiles
content: If no percentile is specified, quantile() returns the 0th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 100th percentiles.

sections.heading: Quartiles
content: Quartiles divide the data into four equal parts.
The first quartile represents 25%, the second 50%, the third 75%, and the fourth 100% of the data.
